content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												The game starts off with you and your hero in a humble little town that you have just aquired. You are given quests that you can follow for rewards, and get you familiarized with the game. In the beginning you are placed in a status with a timer that counts down, and after the amount of ingame hours expire you can now be attacked by armies of relatively the same strength as your own        Or       You can avoid the quests, try and build your army and city your own way, go on the march, start pvp by turning off the protective status mode, going on a coop raid of a city. Whatever you decide to do, the beginning may feel a little harsh because the gathering process feels really slow until you get everything rolling. Your units keep gathering resources while you are offline and there are daily rewards mailed to your in-game bank.The game has a sort of "Knights of Honor" and "Warcraft 3" feel to it. KOH because: There are some diplomacy aspects that can be done with the NPC cities like giving gifts and trading with them to improve relations. NPC cities that you defeat can either be looted for additional resources or placed into vassalage under your command and there are alliances that can be made with other players. When fighting you go into  a zoomed in view where you command you units in the field, give them direct orders of where to attack, what types of formations to use, as well as special abilities that each unit may have. Units can be hot keyed 1-9 on the battlefield to make it easier to bounce between your units. What I like, is that you can mix and match your army for some variety, like taming ogres, or hiring other races as mercenaries to fight for you. There is alot of building that needs to be done to improve your cities defense, offensive capabilites, resource gathering and storage. The buildings also have upgrades on them that can give your units bonuses. There is a population cap in your city depending on the number of houses you build, and different units require different amounts of population requirements, like a dragon requires 10 open slots while knights or archers require 1 slot. You gain veterancy on your units, the more they fight and survive the more levels they will earn. Every level awards 3 points to spend on attack, defense, health cap, stamina cap, or health regen.Warcraft 3 because: As a Realtime strategy that is going on, you have peasant type gatherers, melee units that focus on slashing, crushing and piercing damage. Ranged piercing damage that can be done by archers, there are elite units that you can make like the: tribal shaman, high knight, wizards, multiple types of dragons, while all expensive units to buy, if they fall in battle they will not disappear like a regular unit would. they will just be unavailable till the end of the fight, and then be back in your army again with low health and acouple of veterancy levels lost as a death penalty.The three races you can play as are:Orcs (can build goblin units), Elves (wood elf and high elf) and Humans (can build dwarven units).They all have differences about them, like the range of archers, the defense and offense of melee units, special abilities like heals, hiding and beserk. It all puts a little spin on which race you decide to use.This game is free to play, with a sort of booster shop available in game. You can get the boosters if you want, it will help you get to a more advanced city status quicker, but has a 1 time purchase ability for your city. Its not necessary in order to be competitive or anything like that, it just gives you some gold, and some exta crowns that are required to upgrade some buildings and build advanced strucures and units. You earn the crowns from fights and quests, but the booster and the "premium" status you can pay for will give you some bonus rewards, again not necessary, just available if your the type that has no patience and wants to try and speed things along.Pros:The game as it stands right now is a tremendous amount of fun for me. There is a pretty active community and I like how the story and questing is going, the random coop sieges, the quest battle requests, and the occasional invading enemy army that I either buy off to leave me alone for a while or engage. Different playstyles for different people can be tried out in the skirmish mode. Its like fighting with your army and trying out different tactics without the consequences of losing them in a fight by trying something different. Like I have fought with someone that had an army the same strength as mine but he used only ogres, another used all cavalry sprinkled with some archers. Infantry with cannons. Minotaurs with trebuchets, you name it, alot of variety in what you can use. I like how it only faces you against people that have around the same strength, so your not getting beat down on by the people that have been playing longer than you have. The moderators, like the game masters are always in the chat channel, and can be asked questions anytime in the help channel. They'll offer advice on questions you may have about using units, and suggestions if something with the game is working properly.Cons:The game can seem slow in the beginning. It is meticulous with alot of micromanaging that needs to be done, both in battle and in your town. Building up the wealth required to buy some of the units can be difficult in the beginning of the game if you dont follow the quest line. There have been afew issues that I have seen in chat channel about some people losing some units from their army after the last update, but the Mods have been helping people out. The zoomed in quest giver view, like when you see you character up close and personal when he/she in talking to a quest giver, you can see that they dont look so good, I guess there wasn't alot of emphasis on the polish of the quest givers but not a really big deal. There is also some lag when you are doing a coop battle with someone or logging in, you'll see it get choppy for afew seconds before it smooths out.Well I hope this has helped out with Your decision to play this game. If you are a fan of RTS games I would highly recommend this to you. It's free to download and free to play, I go by the name Ish in game so maybe I'll see you there.

												I love the game. its like all those king and queen games you want all in one. the army battles are huge, the ai does what its told....sometimes atleast. what problems the game has, which to be rather happy with is very little. is fixed within hours or within days. if you let them know whats wrong they will more than likely fix it. its fun to have a huge castle, ive been playing the good part of a few weeks/a month or two and ive barely scratched the surface. the range of units is great. each has strengths/weaknesses nothing is too overpowerd. there really is no spam this unit you win. seige weapons are innacurate but funny but do a lot of damage and whats cool is they use resources to fire. you get raided and the enemy doesnt bring enough resources then good luck him seiging. ive not been attacked yet and you get free premuim on start aswell as not being attacked for 24 ingame hours. not a day if you play or not. your villagers gather resources even when you are not there. the world map is lovingly huge. there is so much to do. you can play as much as you want. there is always something to do. its not like a game you can just leave running and visit an hour or day. you can just keep playing if you want to. it works both ways. the game is great. i hope to keep playing it as much as possible and as long as i can. the graphics are not top end but everything is shown. everything has good animations and the combat is fun. i hope they make graphics a little better but thats my opinion. its a great great game. those who like stratagy games will love this. there is three races too with there own sub factions. humans can get dwarves and mages to help which is cool and as far as i know each race has there own storyline but is on the global map. its great!! keep up the great work!a few things that could be fixed/improved upon. in my opinion and just general fixes that may or may not be noticed that could be done1: The formations and stances can be set but if you log out and rejoin some auto revert without being told otherwise.2: graphics. but thats just me3: a little bit more info on what formations do but not layed out in a basic format. e.g loose formation makes it harder to hit with arrows but does it decrease things in stats, if so by how much, not simply "It reduces this. but not say how much" 4: i would like to see a unit range decal so i know where archers/crossbow men and seige equipment can fire from and where best to place in defence.5. Cycle icons or timers on research and production. there is already a black loading icon but with some research i press the button and its either instant or is researching slowly, either way i cannot tell if its been researched or is researching. maybe grey out the button or say "researched already" e.g the mill, irrigation i researched but it still remains there showing the purchase amount but its no longer clickable, ok i know it means its worked but to others they might click it and go...well what now?6: the mouse feels like it lags when clicking things, sometimes it wont select a unit liturally right behind another unit or when you attack they will walk, maybe a toggle run button too but mainly the way the mouse feels. it seems to feel like its lagging when clicking. or you have to multiple click somethings a few times.7:the female hero after leaving the capital then returning will spawn, when it auto walks to the return way point it walks with a broken graphics, looking like its legs are were its arms are and its arms right outwards with the sword pointing outwards.keep up the good work!

												I want to first start out by saying, I have owned this game since beta, So I have been through all the Bugs and junk like most games when they first come out.....Game Review goes down like thisYou can Custom each unit as well as your Castle, different textures armours and how they fight for example you want Knights with tons of Arrow defense and huge hitting power or low hitting power but can heal up super fast. I guess once you lvl up your units it will somewhat blend in as there are caps...Main types of people you can play ORCS, Elfs and Human. I play Human as my main and Orcs... I hate elves!!! It is not a Pay to win game as it has a system to match people up to somewhat equal balance. The graphics are great, now I have a power house machines so I can't really speak if there is lag or Frame rate issues as I get max all the time. The map and fights are pretty dynamic and if you are a Total War fan this might be your game!! It is also a full RTS game no turn base crap which is nice. I have a O.K army with 1 Red Dragon and a few Minotaurs LOVE Minotaurs. Most people have a lot of playing methods. lots of people like Archers and some like things that can run fast and destroy Archers like Minotaurs hehe. Your Kingdom is setup in such a way that if you get a attacked you have a chance to win if you play smart. You will always retain your Castle if you lose and it is pretty easy to fix it back up.  I would suggest playing solo a few matches to see what your base can do and find the weaknesses. There are plenty of people so lvling up makes it easy. You can lvl up really fast so don't think you will be left behind, this games some what take care of that weakness really good. They have units that you can buy with crowns find out what type of fighter you want to be then unless your power...Crowns that word can be scary but like I said this is not a Pay to win game.... So you can earn crowns pretty easy by fighting and doing all the quest... Now I hope the devs still do this, but they are know to give out 100 crowns for just being nice in chat.... or helping others, I have received close to 300 crowns in total over the years. Devs,, they listen for the most part and seem to have a great connection to the chat channels, patches come out pretty quick and all the extra content is free. PS there is a way to have to have a full Dwarf Army very bad♥♥♥♥♥ I have 50% full army now that I am lvling up. Thank for reading my wall of text..... See you out there

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												Kingdom Wars is not for everyone. It is a slow, complex game, though that's not to say it's any more complex than your average RTS. Starting the game the first time has a steep learning curve of about 7 hours. You have to learn all your normal RTS things like what buildings can go where to make what, what upgrades are available to each unit, basic economy & tactics, etc. But then there is an overworld map, quests, army management, sieges, and a tight constraint on crowns/influence, which is the reward for beating quests and winning combat and absolutely necessary not only for research but for special units, too. And consider this: there is a PvP element, which you either can bypass by paying off the attacker or engage and risk your units, and either way you can only rest safe for one hour of in-game time before you can attack/be attacked again. So you start off with 24 hours of in-game PvP protection. Just 24 game hours to prepare for PvP.PvE is all about quests and getting crowns/influence through quests and battling on the overworld (think random battles from older Final Fantasy games but you choose when & where.) One big flaw is the cumbersome quest system which makes you inch your way over the worldmap to the quest giver's city and then load the city map and then wait while your hero runs across the city to the quest giver. And turning in a quest often results in another one being available, but you have to exit the city and enter it again, walk your hero back to the quest giver and get the next quest in the chain. Most quests are repetitive, and don't directly scale in difficulty. You will often have to fight two armies, seige two cities, etc. and both often occur on the same map, but you have to, again, inch your way over the overworld map to get from point to point. Now the idea behind this is while one army is moving up to four additional armies can be deployed as well. This makes it possible to split your forces and multi-task on the world map, building an ever bigger collective army.Battles can be quick, though. I got to a point in the quests where I decided I would have my hero kill eveything solo, and that takes forever. But if you don't go Hero vs. World, seiging a castle can be quick, routing an army can be quick, it all depends on your playstyle and how much you risk your units, if you worry about looting every penny, spending every skill point asap, etc. This is the kind of game like OgreBattle where you can easily drop 80 hours and not even see a fraction of what there is to achieve in the game. This game is a place to escape reality and become absorbed in the fantasy RTS game, with the added pluses and minuses of PvP. There are so many details, potential strategies, and an ever unlocking complexity that keeps you learning well past the 30 hours I've put into this game so far. Despite the flaws, it is easy to get absorbed. Come and stay. We don't bite - much. :)

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												So Dawn of Fantasy: Kingdom Wars now just known as Kingdom Wars is a rather unique MMORTS with a persistent world and economy.So let's go over this with the good the bad and the improving.The Good:This game has one of the most ACTIVE dev/moderator communities I've ever seen. There are almost always devs or moderators with community supporting abilities online and they respond very quickly to player queries/problems/bug reports.City Management: It's really fun getting your city up and running, your economy working and it really helps build up a feeling of "This is mine!" when you log in to your city.Army building: The roster of units per race is not overly large or cumbersome but there is room for a lot of diversity and tactics. The way they go about this is fairly fun and unique. Each and every battalion levels up  not just the heroes. And as each battalion levels you can allocate points to that battalion so that it better supports your tactics which means you can have two players with say a swordsman battalion and each sword battalion can be the exact same level but be specced out in two totally different ways.This leads to a lot of fun with building YOUR ideal army rather than some all encompassing army of win that so many RTS games have.Battles: Battles in terms of PVP are done via matchmaking which means you won't generally have to worry about armies many times your strength coming down to slaughter you while the veteran player at their helm laughs at the newbie. DON'T be mistaken though because it is fully possible to have two armies of identical strength rating but with totally different power ratios.This can lead to some unforgiving learning cures where you need to figure out ideal combinations to match your strategy. Do you want quantity or quality do you want an ideal mix of both? Are you a player that can micro manage good enough to have a small crack corps of heroes over an army of regular soldiers? ALL of these options and combinations thereof are waiting for you to figure out.PVE: The PVE options to take and conquer AI cities is fun especially when you get co-op up and running and can work together with other players to take particularly difficult targets.Quest system: The quest system while nothing special allows you to earn some extra money and resources while not having to do the more challenging PVE or potentially unforgiving PvP battles.Opt Out: You can "pay off" a player that wants to attack one of your armies or your town so as not to potentially risk losing units you otherwise do not want to lose. This is a good thing as the above mentioned potentially unforgiving early PvP learning curve may cost you questing time/ability.So let's move on to the Bad:Right now you have a few severe bugs that while not game breaking for MOST can become so for the less patient or mature players amongst us. If you get easily frustrated with bugs and don't like having to report them or talk to moderators to get your lost resources/gold/whatever back then at the moment I'd recommend holding off on this game.Can be unforgiving: As stated with the battles section of "the good" this game can be VERY unforgiving when you lose a battle since this is a persistent world those losses are for good and some players might take days to rebuild from the loss of their core army. While most of the community is currently rather friendly and often willing to help new players with tips and tricks on how to get your economy up and running the early losses that players WILL suffer can sometimes be a little spirit breaking until you figure out how to create newer better armies and get a solid economy running.So lets move on to the "Needs improvement":So far the idea that the game is "pay to win" can kind of seem like a thing for new players because of the way crowns work and how slowly they come in for a new player.In truth I think the crown price of some units could afford to be lowered but this is personal preference.There are bugs that definitely need to be sorted out before this game can be a 10/10 and some of the promised features need to be implemented such as the naval options and the like before I can say this game is truly what the developers advertise.So for now at it's current stage I have to give this a 8/10 because it is not really "feature complete". There are bugs some of which can ruin an impatient/less mature player's experience. On the flip side the devs/moderators are extremely active and very willing to help people with any losses they've suffered and for such a small team (6 developers) they are fairly active in attempting to patch and bring this game up to a full 10/10.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												Kingom Wars is, now, one of my favorite games. It let's you mix your long-time strategy such as (building, recruiting and reaserching) with your real time strategy (battles, questing and teaming up with others in co-op or PvP).I have for an long time searched for a game with this concept where you control the whole picture and not only the tiny battlefield OR an entire nations economy and army-positionings, but both!I have played the game for over an month, and for each update it's becoming better and better. The last updates have been really good improvments and I'm sure that is just the start. You might thinkt that the game has become an "pay-2-win" game since it's free now, but as far as I can see, that is not the case. Sure you can speed up things for money or buy some "dragon pack" where you get a dragon or something. BUT! It doesn't ruin the game, at least not for the other players (I haven't bought anything and I feel that I'm on the same terms as anyone I've met). If you're a strategy fan, as me, then I deeply reccomend that you'll at least test the game. The more people playing it, the more action-packed it gets!// Mr.Page

												I love this game cant stop playing it,I havent got to do any pvp yet as my army aint strong enought but looking foward to it also you dont have to spend a penny of your money to win its all completely free.I would recommend doing the tutorial first it dose'nt take long and shows you enough to get started.Pros..as always everything uses resources but they are easy to come by you either farm for them using your peasants, trade goods and livestock for gold to buy them or just buy them with what gold you have instock by going to other towns you can also gather resources by taking peasants out with you to combat to loot the bodys.The building side of the game is easy just click on the building you want to construck and it starts building, it takes time and patients but feels great when you finish, I cant wait till i have a full sized kingdom.When it come to the army its so much fun watching the battles im impressed with the way you can control your individual units unlike some mmo's where its hard to control and keep track of your men this game tops it, the controls are easy just assinge a group to a hotkey and access them at a touch of a button, also the different formations prove very useful when in combat.If your not ready to go out and attack a fort then just go out and you can fight againt pvp who have the same sized army as you,combat is great fun i love watching a hundred men battle it out but its not just a case of run in and chop away you have to be very strategic plan your moves and organise you army accordingly.Cons..I have only one problem.It can get rather expensive on resouces as you kingdom grows so it take a long time to progress.Overall this game is great so get it a.s.a.p

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												The best way to describe this game is by this short sentence: "Real time strategy meets MMO".We all know that will be your response.Well yeah .... the question is ... is it good?Short answer: Yes.Long answer: It's complicated.The good:   - it's free   - the tech tree is quite well defined and the progession is not to difficult    - the units have nice upgrades at level up (and yes the units level up), and it makes sense to have a main army that you carefully level up to a good level and have that as the main force in PVP later on   - the map is quite large and you have the possbility to set small strongholds around the home city to further protect yourself   - the game continues when you are not online (this feature is exaclty what I was searching for)   - large armyes   - ok graphicsThe bad:   - it has quite a few bugs(units sometimes walk thru walls, arrws stuck in mid air, garison units that don't fit the wall are shown at ground level outside the walls ... and so on)   - while map exploring the enemy units are always spawned in the same spot and have the same pathway ... some variation would be great   - sometime the game laggs when in battles (I have an ok PC: octacore AMD and r9-290x, and sometimes I do get these laggs)The bonus ( :D ):   - the administrators here respond real quick to any complanints or bugs you findSoooo here comes the grade:     Considering that I have yet to experience all of it and that it's still a young game, I am able to give it a grade of 7.3 out of 10.PS: If at any point I change my oppinion I'll make sure to change this.

content:
Posted: April 8, 2015
												An excellent game overall, that will immerse most RTS players for at least a good few hours.Its fairly simple, with a very traditional setup of the three factions with strenghts and weaknesses. such as the Humans being the most durable overall, the Elves essentially having the strongest units but with greater weaknesses, and the Orcs being oddly enough the most frail but boasting the ability to quickly amass an army of considerable size at reduced cost.(Please note: This is more of a quick run-down of some of the features in the game, than an review. The idea is that you can more effectively decide if its features appeals to you, rather than read someone trash n praise it)Leveling up your units!:This game relies quite heavily on the concept of your troops not simply being something you purchase enough of, in the right combination but actually take into skirmishes to level up or train at friendly strongholds, to then tailor suit what stats you want to improve, such as more health, damage mitigation, health regeneration, stamina, and so on. Eventually you will pretty much max out all the stats but at that point you have spend quite a lot of gold on that unit, and considering its still very likely to get inconveniently killed while you look the other way you learn to pay special heed to keeping your investments alive and well protected. Special Units:Every faction has an array of faction specific units available to them, but theres also a common pool of special units available to all the factions. These units have roots in all three main factions, but theres also units from unplayable races, such as Dragons and Dwarves. These units almost always costs you Crowns, which is a measure of wealth and influence that you can spend on recruiting considerably attractive units to attack your enemies or defend your homeland.Quest line:Theres an rather involved lore in the game, and its often very nicely attached to the characters you interact with while playing the main quest line. As you go through the main quest of your faction your tasked with defending your homeland, your kingdom, and waging war against the two other factions in the game, and often also your own. Due to the somewhat sandbox-like nature of the game, the senarios you find yourself in is often rather interesting and gradually gives you useful rewards that greatly benefit the construction of your homeland, giving a smooth progression of your homeland, the story of the game, and your involvement in the game overall.Traits and RegionsIn the MMO portion of the game, after choosing a faction you will be asked to choose a region and two traits.These are important and should be chosen to match how you prefer to play the game. If your a "turtle" and enjoys defensive gameplay then naturally you may want to choose the most defensive region and traits, but if your more into siege and conquest than naturally you would do well to take a region that reflects that better.Either way, your choice of region and traits will play an immense factor in the performance of your strategies.Choose wisely. :)Non-Mandatory PvPIn the online MMO portion of the game you may be attacked by enemies at any time, but you need to actually accept the battle. Should you choose not to, or let the timer run out you will forfeit a small portion of your resources as a tribute to be left alone. Even if no resources are available fighting PvP is never mandatory. As you start out with a new homeland you will have 24 hours of real time protection against PvP attacks to get you started. Notice that this time is only ticking while your in-game. Additionally, every time you pay a tribute or conclude a PvP match you will be given a small PvP Protection time.It is also possible to purchase PvP protection for Crowns.The graphics, performance, and the gameplay itself have gradually improved over time, with updates coming out frequently enough for a game you only pay for once. (Not including the micro transaction-like boosts available in the market, and additional features) The gameplay in singleplayer, whether in the online MMO world or not, is very stable but once you have an actual fight not against the AI, but another player it soon becomes a bit of a mess.(This includes co-op aswell) Reasonably playable, yes, but still very annoying at times. However, they have worked hard to improve this game and the future update expected to come out this month, which will apperantly overhaul the entire thing onto a more stable engine will hopefully bring back much of the player base and thus hopefully bring some more life back into this, in all honesty, very awesome game.(If you wish to know more details about the game, i have found a wiki with more details for you)http://strategywiki.org/wiki/Dawn_of_FantasyYes, it does have some problems now and then but this game does deserve a chance if it calls out to you in general.Regards,Brandt.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 8, 2015
												An excellent game overall, that will immerse most RTS players for at least a good few hours.Its fairly simple, with a very traditional setup of the three factions with strenghts and weaknesses. such as the Humans being the most durable overall, the Elves essentially having the strongest units but with greater weaknesses, and the Orcs being oddly enough the most frail but boasting the ability to quickly amass an army of considerable size at reduced cost.(Please note: This is more of a quick run-down of some of the features in the game, than an review. The idea is that you can more effectively decide if its features appeals to you, rather than read someone trash n praise it)Leveling up your units!:This game relies quite heavily on the concept of your troops not simply being something you purchase enough of, in the right combination but actually take into skirmishes to level up or train at friendly strongholds, to then tailor suit what stats you want to improve, such as more health, damage mitigation, health regeneration, stamina, and so on. Eventually you will pretty much max out all the stats but at that point you have spend quite a lot of gold on that unit, and considering its still very likely to get inconveniently killed while you look the other way you learn to pay special heed to keeping your investments alive and well protected. Special Units:Every faction has an array of faction specific units available to them, but theres also a common pool of special units available to all the factions. These units have roots in all three main factions, but theres also units from unplayable races, such as Dragons and Dwarves. These units almost always costs you Crowns, which is a measure of wealth and influence that you can spend on recruiting considerably attractive units to attack your enemies or defend your homeland.Quest line:Theres an rather involved lore in the game, and its often very nicely attached to the characters you interact with while playing the main quest line. As you go through the main quest of your faction your tasked with defending your homeland, your kingdom, and waging war against the two other factions in the game, and often also your own. Due to the somewhat sandbox-like nature of the game, the senarios you find yourself in is often rather interesting and gradually gives you useful rewards that greatly benefit the construction of your homeland, giving a smooth progression of your homeland, the story of the game, and your involvement in the game overall.Traits and RegionsIn the MMO portion of the game, after choosing a faction you will be asked to choose a region and two traits.These are important and should be chosen to match how you prefer to play the game. If your a "turtle" and enjoys defensive gameplay then naturally you may want to choose the most defensive region and traits, but if your more into siege and conquest than naturally you would do well to take a region that reflects that better.Either way, your choice of region and traits will play an immense factor in the performance of your strategies.Choose wisely. :)Non-Mandatory PvPIn the online MMO portion of the game you may be attacked by enemies at any time, but you need to actually accept the battle. Should you choose not to, or let the timer run out you will forfeit a small portion of your resources as a tribute to be left alone. Even if no resources are available fighting PvP is never mandatory. As you start out with a new homeland you will have 24 hours of real time protection against PvP attacks to get you started. Notice that this time is only ticking while your in-game. Additionally, every time you pay a tribute or conclude a PvP match you will be given a small PvP Protection time.It is also possible to purchase PvP protection for Crowns.The graphics, performance, and the gameplay itself have gradually improved over time, with updates coming out frequently enough for a game you only pay for once. (Not including the micro transaction-like boosts available in the market, and additional features) The gameplay in singleplayer, whether in the online MMO world or not, is very stable but once you have an actual fight not against the AI, but another player it soon becomes a bit of a mess.(This includes co-op aswell) Reasonably playable, yes, but still very annoying at times. However, they have worked hard to improve this game and the future update expected to come out this month, which will apperantly overhaul the entire thing onto a more stable engine will hopefully bring back much of the player base and thus hopefully bring some more life back into this, in all honesty, very awesome game.(If you wish to know more details about the game, i have found a wiki with more details for you)http://strategywiki.org/wiki/Dawn_of_FantasyYes, it does have some problems now and then but this game does deserve a chance if it calls out to you in general.Regards,Brandt.

content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												Genius game! Pros: Slowpased fighting and building which gives you a lot of time to figure out strategies.         Fighting mechanics are very easy to understand when you've played a few games.         Should be lag free on most computers Cons: Tutorial needs a lot of improvement. It only teaches you how a small part of the humans works. If you want to play any other race as first race, you'll barely understand anything of the game. I began as elves, played for a short while and was then going to uninstall the game, because it was confusing. Luckily I decided to try humans, and that's how I learned the game. So basically you can skip tutorial, it doesn't teach you anything, other than the things you learn from every other game you play. It totally forgets the things it's supposed to teach, like what's unique about this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												Rating: 9/10Pros:-Works like a Facebook game, you can log out with peace of mind knowing that players cannot attack you unless you are online. And you get rewarded for daily log-ins!-If you are a rich and prosperping player, you might be able to pay them off with gold or stone, etc.-Feels like Stronghold - but without the pesky tasks of "cleaning up gong" or "peseants stealing from our granery sire" -Mobile armies: You can build a force and level them through campsites and taking on enemies in the wilderness around you, making you stronger and your units stronger for battles to come.-Well designed lore of castles and beautiful landscapes.-No "PayToWin": As they say in the news on the game "this game is designed to avoid the pitfalls of FreeToPlay games....focusing more on skill and persistance than bigger wallets"Cons:-Very wonky (slow) combat. You have to make sure you units don`t get stuck and cluttered as they will get moved over by the smallest force if you`re not careful.-Co-op is not as smooth as I had hoped, while you can send supplies to your friend, getting them to play with you to aid in a quest or seige is a bit frustraing if you dont pay close attention to what you are selecting.-Npc workers [peasants, etc] tend to get stuck up in hills or behiind fences when chopping down trees. -The initial title screen has very LOUD audio - first tiime players make sure your audio is turned down some or your ears will get blasted away. While this is epic sounding, if any player has their volume up they might get quite a surpize once the tittle screen loads.-Slow loading screens between transitions. [ While this really isn`t a *con* it can be annoying waiting for that bar to load up when there is little to nothing in your home city to load ] Another transition issue is between begining to seige and actually entering the seige. These problems are on and off, and while I havea solid internet this *may* vary between players. Overall this game as great potential to kick out Stronghold and its gong-infested cities and brings forth a potential for a shining sheild in castle-sim-like games.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												Greetings steam comunity,5cents on why this game is recommendet by me and why you should waste a part of youre precious livetime playing it.First of all - why should one play it?- its fun- its free- its got castels- its got dragons (some of them slightly three headed)- its got mad magics- its not a pay2winTo give this a more serious aproach - the pro stuff:+ The game is a fine mixed castle building, army training and stuff wrecking experience(, a little of what i wanted as a stronghold fan :) ).+ Three playable races - elves, man and orcs.+ The gameplay of the battles is well done. Whyle the overal controling mechanism is rather simple one may invest some energy into the micromanagement of unit stances and rotations to gain the best from the troops efforts.+/- The castle is limited to a few number of designs and placement spots - which are nicely done to alow the player a rather wide range of tactical options.+ The Armys consist of up to 60 units, including sige engines and workers to get all those shiny coins from the corpses. As the units gain experience they may be upgradet to fit the players needs.+ The KI citys are chalanging and differ greatly in theyr designs+ The pvp system seems promising, presenting some late game challange, interesting battles and army compositions and the rather easy and fair mechanics of avoiding it by paying a part of ones ressources to the attacker.+ The overal unit ballancing seems to be sound and while its not perfect the developers are working to improve it.+ The comunity is alive and quite friendly.To play it is a little like....One may upgrade his camp to a formidable stronghold. While the walls rise high the troops may march to complete the first quests and plunder some stuff on the way. By doing so one aquires the in game currency of crowns - and even if there is a rather great heap of those in the in game store, the number one may get there is limited.In time the army will get experienced and gain enough power to take on the great citys of the world. The choice between looting a vanquished city or taking it on as a vassal is rather rewarding - more so if you just managed to gain a victory inside the walls of the capital :).On the dark side ther are a few things to be said:- The KI is just not up to the task. While the unit KI is ok with only some minor *whydoyoustupidhealersengagetheogersinmeeleagain >.<* kind of problems the KI troops on the battlefield remain stationary until engaged, most of the time. Most of the movements an enemy will do are rushing his remaining troops into the keep, if you break don its gate, and some counter charges if this gate did not belong to the keep. The odd exeption is a charge of the reinforcement troop. Those apear after half an hoer into a KI sige and are pathetically easy to block, by disengaging your troops from the city and mincing the reinforcements. - The ballancing of the fractions is not finished yet. The orc race seems to be a little on the downside, in the overal army performance.- There are few end game challanges out of pvp matches. If one has put some thought into the army composition and the upgrading of ones troops there will be next to nothing left to stop this army.-/+ The game is still in the making. While not essentialy bad, one may get slightly annoied by a few bugs and gliitches. Also ive experienced two mayor bugs up until now, of the *dude where is my castle?* kind. On the other hand: those where solved in a matter of one or two days and the mods did theyr best to recompensate the losses. Also one may hope to see some further improvements to the gameplay and some more content to come.oh, and cookies, because.... you know....In summa summarum i recommend this game.Hope to see you (try) torching my city some time :),best regards, Cyraion.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
												I've been looking for a game that melds a lot of features from some of my favourite strategy games into an online environment, a game that is set aside from others within the same genre, and this really is it. The game is not pay to win and is paced really well, it's not slow nor is it fast, you really feel rewarded from what you receive through the steady rate of progression. The quests help to push you in the right direction while you're starting out, and after just a few hours you'll be making some really steady progress toward the more end-game options. Positives: As mentioned previously, the game is not pay to win, finding a game like this that is both enjoyable, f2p, and not pay to win seems to be the gaming equivalent of finding gold in your back garden, for this I am very grateful. You have several different options in terms of how you would like to play the game, do you want to be economically focused, do you want to focus on military, etc; this kind of choice makes the game strategically diverse and allows you to shape how you want to play the game, and I felt that this made the game far more enjoyable, especially if you play with friends and work together by taking up different roles.Negatives: The game is a little buggy right now, and performance can vary. While trying to use the windowed mode feature I found my game crashing very frequently, and I ultimately had to disable that option. I also got stuck in one of the tutorials while trying to access the menu. So the game is definitely in need of some polish. Combat could also do with some work; the current system gets the job done but is quite clunky and very messy. You send your units in and then sit back and hope for the best. Of course the graphics are quite basic but they are bearable, a slight overhaul would be a nice quality of life improvement. A little more direction for players completely new to the genre would also be very useful. Overall, from my gameplay experience and from the masses of reading I've done about the game, I think it's great and absolutely worth a try. The developers are keen on improving the game and are asking for feedback whenever possible, which really tells me they have their head in the right place.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 23, 2015
												Kingwom Wars I still remember my thrill when I heard about this game being released. If I had to explain this game in one sentence it would be: The game is like Travian, Tribal Wars, ... but in real time 3D RTS mode.I have little play time on steam, that is because steam release was buggy at start, it payed off more to play using official launcher, meaning not using steam. The gameplay is simple, you start with a town which you upgrade. It has no deep depth of techology, it is rather simple and straight forward. You do not even need super strong economy to get decent army. I mostly play Elfs since I find their economy and troops most suitable to me (Archers :) ). Game has single player and multiplayer side which do no differ too much. You can play singleplayer offline with no problems, multiplayer gets you closer to other players. Multiplyer is same as singleplayer but you can go into CO-OP battles with other players, either with or against them. Maximum players inbattle are 2v2, which is kinda limiting. Guild/Clan/Alliance has meaning in terms helping each other during attacks. Game itself looks like Total wars series where troops and cities are managed on global map, while battle itself is in spirit of total war series where 2 armies clash. Combat system is same as with total war series archers(mounted, foot, crossbows), infantry(heavy knights, pikemen, swordsmen), cavalry (one type mounted knight, elfs have mounted archers), monsters with orcs etc. Each unit formation could lvl till 20 and had stat points for you to manually upgrade which provides decent ammount of depth. Each unit type has its special skills, where some have to be researched using crows, which are acquired with battles and quests. At start it was that simple, during time game developers kept close contact with comunity and invested great time to fixing bugs and providing new content. At release time game was once time purchase, now it is free to play model with premium. New content added mages, dragons, dwarfs, new heroes/special units, sieges but for all of it you need massive ammount of crowns which arent easy to get. There are also some bugs where you spend 250 crowns, but s*it happens, server reverses your upgrade and town state and u lose 250 crowns which finally made me quit game. Game itself is fun and worth playing, developers are moving forward and wont forsake the game, but KW2 is comming and you can feel that they are more focused on that release. Have fun it is nice game.

content:
Posted: October 21, 2016
												This is not worth your time, at first glance a "MMORTS" sounds fun. But there are huge problems with pathfinding, ever see a army you spent hours building up walk into siege fire and die? this game will do it. most of your battles will be farming the same area of the map repeatedly for "crowns" a currency you can farm or buy from the shop. I spent two days building an army and had no way to get any more crowns, the minimap in your battles is horrendous and isnt even working in real time, it ♥♥♥♥ing updates off of refreshes every couple of seconds. the graphics are so poor you sometimes cant pick out smaller units from the terrain. I dont even know how to structure all of the problems. If it was one or two big things fine, its an indie dev. But there are so many small things wrong with the game that the act of playing the game forces you into a battle with the game itself, you have to fight the bad game design to play this. and thats a real shame, i want to love it.

content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
												I noticed that a lot of people are not recommending this game because of the feature, "Pay to win", is in the game but that is entirely optional. You don't have to pay. You only pay for the game with everything in it. Nothing forces you to pay. Not sure if that feature is still in the game though.Also I saw one review saying that you have to join the game by signing up on their website. That is not true although You have to register ingame and then receive an confirmation email for you to complete the registeration. This process do not take more than two minutes. You are required to do this in order to play the game online with friends and others. That's it.Anyway my review...Overall and ongoing, it is a fun game. I enjoy playing against AIs enemies as well as players whilst doing the storyline. I use the term, storyline, very loosely because it is almost very direct but you can do the quests whenever and in your own time. Yes, the game can and should have been better than what it is at the moment but I don't complain because it is a decent game.However it can be ugly due to cutscenes when you have conversations with some certain characters in the "storyline." The characters, by looking very closely, they look like they came from 90s games like Castle Strike or the old Warcraft series unless I forget to improve the graphics in the settings lol but that is manageable anyway because you don't look that closely often.Overall, I would say this is 7/10. Better than some games but could have been better.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
												Kingdom Wars is a very interesting game. At first I had a very low opinion of it, but if you can overcome the first hour of the game and look past its shortcomings you'll find a very addictive experience with so much potential.Negative impressions: Visually it looks as if it made in the early 2000s, and the combat leaves a lot to be desired. Once battle is joined unit formations devolve into disorganized mosh-pit like globs with very poor unit collision detection (if any at all.) The animations are primitive and very basic, not just in combat but for walking, idle, and cutscenes dialog. There are also a host of bugs, many of which are highly destructive and infuriating. The worst I encountered was when I lost an entire army, 28 units, because a quest sent them into a void and left me with an empty army on the map- without even starting the quest. I was left without my hero unit, and an entire day worth of invested resources that I used to build said army.Positive Impressions: The economic system and a load of fun, and by far the best part of the game aside from the general idea. You can make profits by trading, harvesting resources, looting battlefields, and questing. Each option presents its own benefits and challenges. If you decide to harvest resources at home then you will looking at the safest and most reliable way, but it also means you need peasants working the land which drags on your unit cap. Trade is the quickest way, but it also means you’re at risk of losing caravans and thus your cargo. It also requires more management and the natural risk of losing money on a trade if you’re too hasty.The game has a pretty mild pace, which is certainly a positive in my opinion. You won’t become powerful overnight, and all buildings and soldiers take quite a bit of resources and time to make. There is also a healthy variety of units and plenty of defining traits to pick from. Units gain experience from battles which lets you upgrade them, in addition to researching new technologies and equipment. From what I can tell there is no pay-to-win advantage either. The cashhop is purely aesthetics and speeding up the process of questing rewards.If the combat would be overhauled then I think this would be an easy game to recommend, and if animations and visuals where modernized then it would be a jewel. However as it stands it’s a give and take. If you can overlook its issues there is a lot of fun to be had, but not everyone can do that.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												This game is one of my favorite RTS games of all time, but it is also still in progress, which means it can only improve from its current state (Still great in its current state). I have about 90 hours in the game at the moment, but with the new progress on the game right now, I can't wait to get back into the game. The developers are communicative and work with community to make the game better for everyone. The game reqiures strategic units and positioning to overcome defenses and overwhelming numbers. Kingdom Wars also allows you to make a town from scratch and build it into a fortress, along with controlling massive armies to conquer the many cities on the map. The progression of your city is slow but that make every little addition to your city feel huge. The campaign is mostly missions to keep you busy and have something interesting to do, but they give a good amount of gold. You are allowed to choose between three races: elves, humans, and orcs. Each have their own strengths and defenses, which means a variety of different play styles, thus giving the game replay value if you ever wish to restart. I definitely would recommend this game to any of my friends because it also allows you to team up with them to take down strongholds and do missions. If I was to rate this game on a scale of 1 to 10, I would say it was a 12. Kingdom Wars is phenomenal and I can't wait to see what they have in store for it in the future.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 7, 2014
												Definitely a must for all RTS fans. Especially since it is free, right? Unlike most game's that are free, this one also comes with the guarantee that it isn't pay to win. Wait one second. Free game not being pay to win? That's right! Paying in game with hard currency does not give you an outrageous advantage over people who choose not to pay and many options are simply for visual effects like battle standard and the like. Ha I'm gonna make my army bear the picture of an electric guitar. What? There weren't electric guitars back then? Darn.Well anyways, This game is in my words: "A more drawn out MMO version on Age of Empires." Set in the medieval time period. Here you get to build your city, raise armies, capture enemy strongholds then choosing whether to control them or simply plunder them, and that's just the tip of the iceberg. As for you mythical lovers, there's also dragons, and wizards, and dwarves, Oh my! Choosing between three races is pretty cool, but here you can also select unique traits to focus your race on. Let's see here... Orcs with reduced market rates and prices? Umm no. I'll take combat mastery and take the goods I want by force haha. Fear me you peasants! Ah sorry, I let my power hungry self out again... Let's continue shall we? I don't know about you but with over 20 enemy cities to siege, 3 regions for each race with other unexplored territories, and the ability to enter the world on any part of the map for different experiences, there is clearly a nice feeling of change to keep you refreshed. There is also a very competitive player versus player system as this being it's main aspect and a great co-op feel, although it beautifully sows player versus environment elements into the game even giving the option to quest and play the game solo.While the game still has many bugs (many of them being quite annoying), it is completely compensated by the amazing staff that keeps the game afloat. I've never seen a game change and advance as quickly as it has to find and fix problems affecting everyone and even problems affecting one person! One bug here, next day solved. Great game you must give it a try it is truly the next RTS brought to life. It's here... And it's evolving as we speak.Till next time,                   Canine (In-game name: FrozenSteel, Referal code: REF1100001083111D8)

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 10, 2014
												DON'T BE FOOLED!In a battle of The Good, The Bad, and ugly, this game defiantly comes out on top. It has a very unique style in its class, a great community, and Devs who listen and respond to its players. The game provides plenty of features, lots of different tactics to try, and does a good job rewarding you for hard work. Let's break it down:The GOOD:- Lots of units to mix match and unlock- I love research, upgrading, and expanding. Everything from buildings to individual units- Crazy epic and awesome units are immortal. Meaning when you save up all your crowns to get that dragon. You love him, pet him, and feed him, give him a great home and BAM! Some glory dragon slayer slays your dragon! (Noooo) But no worries, he may lose a few levels of experience, but he is not lost forever!- I love how epic my cities feel. In the early stages of the game things feel slow. A little humpty-Dumpty, but the pace quickly picks up. Especially when you start sieges.- Siege Battles!- The real money exchange system isn't a pay to win. They have boosts to help get your city going, but most everything else is aesthetics.- Co-OP options are awesome. When doing something that you need a little extra oomph… Go Co-Op!The Bad: - What can I say, games got bugs. While Kingdom Wars has eliminated most of the 'Show Stoppers' an occasional boot out of a battle, or a vanishing GUI can still provide headache. Even though the developers have done a great job reimbursing any lost time / effort, it's still a hassle.- Friends / Guilds / Chat system is a little clunky. Sometimes it's hard to tell when someone is online, or directly chatting with you.- I have mixed feelings about the map. Part of me wishes we could see other player cities, while another part says this is a very interesting setup. I like not being camped, people sitting outside my city waiting for protection to fall, but on the other hand. I kind of miss doing it?The Ugly: - The biggest complaint I have about the game is some of the weird, jerky movement in battle. I hate having to issue orders multiple times to get a unit to perform a special task.- Though I love Co-Op, sometimes finding someone to help you perform a task is… troublesome. Sometimes I sit for 15+ minutes looking for someone to siege with me.- The popup messages are troublesome. They ask or provide you with certain information. "Would you like to vessel a city, or loot it for xx crowns." If you don't answer before another message is triggered you lose both options. Being invited to a Co-Op is sometimes confusing. Yes it tells you the name or quest, but it zooms so far into the map, it's hard to tell where you really are.Overall, I would highly recommend the game. The units, city building, and unique features add a very refreshing spin on the RTS genre. The Free to play is truly free as you will not find a hidden 'Pay to win' market. The community is helpful, and the Developers are extremely repsonsive. Raise a mug to Kingdom Wars!

												I really love the gameplay of this game and the combat,siege and defense mechanisms. The grapgics are really good and detailed for a strategy RTS game. However, while yes it technically is not pay to win, its more pay to play. I was very surprised to find that i couldnt even play a skirmish without paying, while i can understand the developers need to make money, i wouldn't call it free to play if 3/4 of the features require actual money. A good example of an ACTUAL free to play is Neverwinter; every single ounce of content is free, even the things you can only get with special items is still achievable using multiple methods in the game, on top of that it's solid, fun, addictive and satisfying gameplay and story. So while im very into Kingdom Wars i think making it fully free to play or even just unlocking the skirmish modes would bolster the popularity and reception of the game.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												Kingdom Wars is an RPG Indie-Strategy game. It takes place long ago. You can choose from being Elves, Men, or Orcs. You are also able to choose from three different starting locations. As you progress through the game, you learn more and more about the lore. I, truly, very much like this game. It has all the things I like. If you have ever played Sid Meier's Civilization IV, Beyond the Sword/Warlords, or Civilization V, you will notice a lot of similarities. This game will keep you occupied for hours, and I, personally, reccomend this game to people like me who LOVE old fighting styles, and LOVE a good RPG/Strategy game.9.5/10 I'm sure there are many great things to come with this game.

Kingdom WarsBefore you read my ratings understand that i consider a score of 20 and below to be a bad game a score between 20 and 30 a decent gamea score between 30 to 40  to be a good gameand a score of 40+ to be a awesome game Priceworthy - 10/10 Consider the fact that you don't pay anything for the game. Graphics - 7/10 looks decently good. Sound - 6/10 somewhat decent music in the game. Gameplay - 7/10 i really like the game but getting tormented in pvp sucks. Worth playing - 7/10 The game is worth experiencing.Kingdom wars gets a total score of 36 out of 50This is a truly great game but as all games that don't have the backing of a multi million dollar company it has its big flaws like some latency to other players and somewhat odd pathfinding for units at times, but as we gamers know they are trying to patch whatever the problem is it won't be instant but they are working on it. The 2 somewhat bad things in this game is the really unbalanced "HERO" units,and the really really unbalanced pvp system.I Would really recommend this game if you are a RTS Fanor really just want to play a rts game with a friend.

content:
Posted: April 24, 2015
												Well i may not have played for a long period of time in this game and it seems like i cannot login into the game now due to some bugs. I still think this is a good game overall, which is why even after i encounter a rare bug which still have had yet to be solved and the developers are working on it. The pros and cons are much like what other players have posted out in the reviews. I personally think the most attractive thing about kingdom wars are the pvp system and city protection shield. Unlike other games, this city protection shield only tickles when you are online on your kingdom and playing. When you go offline, your shield will be the same as when you login again. That is extremely attractive for players like me who are busy at work with little time to play games everyday. In other games, you will normally get sieged and lose resources or even the whole kingdom and you have to restart again which is very frustrating. Here, you can take things slowly as you want, explore the maps, conquer some npc cities or co-op siege with the community. If you have the time and army, you can just remove your shield and get onto some pvp for more fun.There are no worries on how you play and whether if there are overpowered players that pays to win as everyone is more or less the same depending on what strategy you use and time spent to experience the game. I hope everyone finds it fun to play too.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2016
												I saw the video and read up on the game a bit and liked to co-op assist feature online for attack and defense.  Also, I was hoping the game was not as dark as the video, but it's just as dark if not darker for some areas on maps.  The movement of the troops was clunky at best and not based on lag or GPU/CPU/RAM, but just clunky as created.  The UI is very outdated and plain (some games had this 15 years ago).  So for a rerelease = not too good.  Nothing really else stood out as amazing or stand-outish in a way that really grabbed continuing insterest.  The castle building is expected at best.  The one thing in movement that stood out most was the inability to click to move around some objects and not much transparent environment when a unit is behind it; not that units get lost, but in the heat of battle it could make some difference.  The last killer is that there is no Multiplayer really, unless you play with friends.  I saw mainly 1 or 2 online games, but that is about it.  Also, in PvE the A.I. is mediocre at best.I would suggest some other RTS like Stronghold; which is very similar, if not what this game is trying to clone.So unless some changes are made I can't recommend this game.  I was hoping to, but like I said there is nothing really too unique or anything that stands out as great, just expected remakes of this & thats in other games of the Genre.

number of helpful: 8 of 17 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												After playing this game for 12 hours it's clear this is a free to play, or pay to win game (just about pay to play).  The developers say they aren't going for that pay to win game however the time it takes to build anything is staggering without paying.  Everything in the game costs crowns which you earn by completing quests, killing a players army, playing co-op, or defending your keep.  By no means a small amount of crowns either so basic upgrades cost 10~120 crowns each.  Note that defending your keep doesn't happen often enough to make gathering crowns in that manor a viable option.  You can purchase crowns which makes the game go quicker as you also get gold when you do this to boot.  Thus making the game actually playable if you pay.The delevopers give out a starting bonus deal to help new players get into the game.  Compared to how slow the game moves, the bonus didn't make that much difference.  The issues is simple resource generation bonus for 10 minuts at the x10, x8, x6, and x4 level, and a 5 hour x2 resource generation.  I stopped playing before that ran out as I couldn't imagine playing the game at normal resource generation without pulling my hair out.  You also won't get attacked by anything for the first 24 hours.  To be honest I cancelled the protection as soon as I started to see if I would even get attacked at all.  I didn't at 12 hours of play get attacked once.  Which kind of makes having a walled village pointless.The game itself has a good concept.  The graphics are okay but not great, the sounds, and music is garbage, the game play is kind of interesting.  The bugs are many.  The biggest issue is that it's a 100% server sided game.  I can log out and get more resources than I can while playing due to the lag between the server and my game.  I have an above average rig that can handle any game out on ultra settings so no it's not my computer.  If your army dies there is a glitch that doesn't reset your population count at your home base cuasing some issues trying to rebuild an army.The main reason I don't recommend this game is becuase there is so much work involved with building an army after you get defeated, or even just play and win a battle.  Compaired to the loot you receive from a battle the cost of building an army is crazy.  An army can cost around 1,000 resources per unit with an army cap of 90 units it can get expensive.  The first major battle in the game requires around 25 units to beat.  However the losses are about 20 units.  The treasure gained is around 2,000 gold and about 400 wood and a crown or 2.  The 20 units cost around 30,000 food, and about 15,000 gold.  You don't gain land, units, or anything else in the first major battle.  It was cool to watch just not cool enough to waste 5 hours rebuilding another army to go on the next mission.The peasant AI is horrible as well, and the gathering of resources is limited at best.  Some of the peasant resource gathering upgrades are bugged and actually don't improve what they say they will.  Which is similar to placing buildings, some locations are even bugged and you can't place anything there.  You have to choose wisely what you will place as you are limited to so many slots unless you get an upgrade to the slots of buildings you can place.  Which also requires crowns, and a lot of them.  The population cap in town might be to blame for everything wrong with the game.  With a glitch that doesn't calculate the population correctly, to not showing you all of your peasants when you click on the view all button it would seem the developers haven't finished this game yet.  The population cap is sitting at 90.  While I was able to max mine out at 50 in town after having to use population for animals to get extra food resources I found that I couldn't generate enough to build an army of 30 in a day.  It took about 5 hours to get a army of 25 going.  After that main battle which lasted about 5 minutes.  Having to rebuild all but 4 of those units there simply wasn't enough motivation to continue playing the game.If the developer reads this I would recommend focusing on fixing any bugs the game has.  I would also lower the cost to upgrade anything with crowns in the game.  I would also rewrite the treasure you get after a battle to match the size of the battle, and the losses you will take on at an even matched battle.  If you lose you get nothing, if you win you get enough to at least repair, or rebuild most of your army.  The resource generation is so slow that it would take weeks to get anthing interesting going not to mention all the crowns I'd need just to upgrade my town hall to a castle might take months.  I would recommend changing the population cap to 100 for peasants, or fix the resource generation to make the game pace faster.  Playing 1 battle every few hours is dull and boring after all.  As the name of the game isn't kingdom building it's kingdom war. Compared to other games out there I can play that in this genra this game comes in as boring, and slow at best.  It has a ton of potential to be great, it just simply isn't at this time.

												built lots of soldiers, next time I logged in, they disappeared.Even worse, knowing that my cool-down was coming to an end, I slowly and tirelessly gained gold to exchange for crowns (the p2w currency) and eventually started building the cage, which would allow me to get a dragon/hydra to defend myself.To put things into perspective: to get one crown, you have to spend 5 thousand gold, I started in the region with the most minerals, and even then I got only 10k per day, amounting to 2 crowns, even if I sold all the remaining resources for as much gold as I could, I still managed to do 4 crowns a day, that's 10 days of not doing anything but gathering gold that you spend only on the p2w currency.When I came back today, having patiently waited the 12 hours that would take to build it, I was greeted by a surprise:Not only did my cage simply vanish into nothing, but all the resources I spent on building it disappeared with it! That's days upon days of tireless un-fun work gone to hell, 40 crowns vanished into thin air.Unless you want this to happen to you, don't play it, it's practically stronghold:kingdoms with better graphics and a (bad) skirmish mode anyways.

But overall I'd give this game a 5/10.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
												A game targeted at all Stronghold, LOTR:BFME, and Age of Empire fans.Task villagers to harvest resources, build up your castle/stronghold, raise armies to go questing/clearing areas/sieging/pvp, all while the units in said armies gain ranks and can become quite powerful.Battles take place Total War style, the only setback is the fact that unit collision has little to no effect, battalions don't stick together, so tactics have a somewhat reduced effect here. Bringing villagers to battle is actually mandatory, because looting the fallen yields amazing amounts of resources, especially from PVP.After any PVP (field battle or siege) you get some PVP protection time, so you're not overwhelmed from annoyingly nonstop PVP. Although, keepi in mind that the rewards from participating in PVP are quite bountiful. If you don't want to participate, a small bribe is possible, which is proportional to the army size. Smaller armies = smaller payouts. You do get PVP protection after a payout so it is possible to skip the whole PVP deal alltogether.There is a special resource (crowns) which is necessary for all upgrades and high level units. It comes quite slowly at the beginning, but are most certainly attainable without paying real money. Ammasing gold is the way here, because crowns can be bought for gold at a rate of 1:5000. A solid economy is key, which is a must for any player of this type of game.Solid game, If you loved Stronghold, BFME, or Age of Empires you should definitely try this one.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 11, 2015
												If you've ever played an economy focused RTS like Age of Empires, built up a flourishing and efficient town over the course of a match, and then felt a twinge of sadness on the statistics screen at the loss of said town, then Kingdom Wars is a good bet. (Especially for the low low price of completely free.)Early game you'll spend most of your time optimizing your economy. Training more peasants, setting them to mine gold or stone, gather lumber or farm the fields, meanwhile using your small starting militia to complete the basic quests.After a day or two however that part of the game virtually disappears, with you making only a few adjustments now and then. The economy does everything it needs to, but not a lot more. The main meat of the game is BATTLE. :DPVP works like so:1: Put together an army that you built in your town, and bring it onto the world map.2: Click the "Search pvp" button and choose between attacking a city or fighting an army head on.3: If you're fighting an army you'll find yourself on a small open map with some mountains and a few camps of neutral forces.4: If you're in a siege the layout of the land can differ greatly depending on the homeland of the player. Siege weapons are required of course.5: Rewards for winning is gold that you loot of the bodies and Crowns just for winning.The actual combat is squad based, similar to Total War.You can switch between different formations to optimize various types of defence, movement speed and damage. Troops will level up as they participate in battle, allowing you to spend ability points to increase their stats.It's very worth bringing up the F2P platform, as many people shy away from games like this based on the fear of a Pay to Win barrier popping up in their way every time they were just starting to enjoy the game.Cutting to the chase, you don't ever need to spend money in this game. There is a currency called Crowns which you can gain through the following means:1: Winning any ingame fight - either against the AI or players2: Finishing quests3: Paying for it through microtransactionsThing is though, in the case of this game you don't really pay to gain an advantage as much as you do to skip large sections of the game. Sure, you can buy a ton of Crowns in the store and get loads of endgame units and be matched with the best players, but then you lose out on all of the Battles and Sieges that, assumedly, are the reason you are there in the first place.It is currently not possible to actually take control of AI castles, but this will be changed in an upcoming free expansion.PS: Don't pick the human female hero. The voice acting will drill it's way into your skull.
